Review Text: São Camilo Hospital… A bastion of health in São Paulo, where I have been cut (literally) in surgeries, where my wife has fought battles in the ICU and where I have paraded countless times in orthopedics in just one year.Medicine? Cutting edge. The screening? Impeccable. The pros? Angels in lab coats. But… oh, the ticket window!This is where the surrealism of Brazilian bureaucracy finds its apotheosis. The setting? A mosaic of exhausted faces, passwords that never flash on the panel and a rhythm that would make even a turtle stop for a cup of coffee. Would a hospital of this size, with the level of excellence you have, be beaten at the start by a ticket window? It's almost poetic. Or tragic. It depends on the point of view.The experience of waiting for a ticket at São Camilo is practically a forced meditation on the fragility of life. It's an existential test, a reminder that while the heart beats, the system operates in its own time. It's not a wait; it is an initiation. A rite of passage. And, honestly, it's a lack of care that doesn't match the perfection you deliver in all other aspects. Thank you, ANS.Suggestion to the governing body: How about an anthropological experience? Break a leg. Literally. Or tear a ligament, face a panic attack or, who knows, a mysterious rise in blood pressure. But, before throwing yourself into the welcoming arms of professionals, try to survive the odyssey at the ticket window. It's a guaranteed epiphany. Life takes on another dimension when you realize that your biggest rival at the hospital is… a password.And, if the issue is parking, I would just like to say one thing: Estapar should be banned in São Paulo. There is nothing more to say.Finally, reinforcement: Saint Camilo, you are giants. But please, prove your greatness in the basics as well. Hire more people for the counters. Because no patient deserves to have their life put on hold while the panel decides to spin.

I sat down in a lot of pain, a little clumsy, and within a few minutes I was seen by a young, friendly and objective doctor regarding my situation. We talked, she medicated me, requested tests, and I remained under observation throughout the morning in the most comfortable way possible for a 10 out of 10 pain patient, sitting in an emergency room chair. In the morning, I was re-evaluated by another doctor, a little older, but equally charismatic and decisive. He informed me about the stone, its location after the tomography, contacted the urology team, and decided to admit me for surgery on the same day as my pain did not subside even with a few doses of morphine. I spent the whole morning under another observation. , for more or less 6-7 hours until I was admitted, but always with people asking me how I was, medicating me, taking care of me. Away from home and alone about to undergo surgery! I went up to my room at 2:30 pm. I went to the surgical suite at 3:30 pm, after getting ready, taking a shower and changing. Standard procedures for this surgery in this hospital. I spoke to the anesthesia team and was instructed on how the anesthesia would be performed, before during and after the procedure. I spoke to the surgeon, for the first time for more than a minute, as the emergency room was busier and there wasn't much time. I explained my situation of being from afar and he was ready to give me written instructions so that I wouldn't have any problems post-operatively. We went into the operating room. Everything was fine during the surgery and in the immediate post-operative period. I went down to the room, with a friendly and careful stretcher bearer.
